CARDINAL . On DATE a prosecutor at ORG again refused to institute criminal proceedings on the grounds of a lack of a criminal element in the death . In particular , the prosecutor held that there was no evidence that PERSON had been ill - treated , as alleged by the applicant . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG overruled the prosecutor ’s decision and remitted the case to the prosecuting authorities for a new examination . The court pointed out the inconsistencies as to when the fire had begun . The court held that the fact that the car transporting FAC had broken down could not explain such a long delay . CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge of the case again refused to institute criminal proceedings . The wording of the decision was identical to that of CARDINAL DATE , except the last few paragraphs , which concerned the conditions of detention of inmates suffering from epilepsy . In that connection , relying on statements made by the head of the prison regime department of ORG and GPE , the investigator found that domestic law did not provide for any special conditions of detention for inmates suffering from epilepsy or any restriction on the authorised items they could possess in prison .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG overruled the investigator ’s decision of DATE and remitted the case to the prosecuting authorities . The court held that the investigator had failed to examine the reason for the delay in PERSON ’s transfer to hospital . It also pointed out the inconsistencies in the inmates’ statements concerning the circumstances of the incident . The court further found that it had not been established whether ORG conditions of detention had been compatible with his illness and that an inquiry should have been carried out as regards the necessary security and medical measures for a person like PERSON , whose condition was likely to give rise to sudden seizures .

CARDINAL . On DATE a prosecutor at ORG again refused to institute criminal proceedings , using wording that was almost identical to the decisions of CARDINAL DATE and DATE . The prosecutor found that it had been PERSON ’s fault that the fire had broken out and that he had died as a result of his burns . He further held that the prison guards had taken immediate action and there had been no negligence on their part . He also confirmed that there had been a delay in taking FAC to hospital because the car had broken down . He further found that it had not been possible to carry out a forensic fire examination as the scene of the incident had not been preserved .
